Preparing to Wrap a PVCS Project

The wrapping process must be performed on a computer that has the Windows client installed and a hierarchy of archived PVCS files on its hard drive. Before you perform the wrapping process, you must prepare for this operation.

To prepare for wrapping:

  1. Install PVCS on the computer that runs the Server. The Server must be running.

    2. The user running the server process must have execute privileges for the PVCS library, usually C:\Program Files\PVCS\VM\Win32\Bin. This can be verified by executing the vlog program. Depending on how PVCS was installed, this may involve modifying the user ID membership in particular user groups or the protection attributes on the PVCS installation files. See the PVCS Version Manager Installation Guide.

  2. Verify that the PVCS Bin folder is in the computer's path statement. Otherwise, neither the PVCS command line nor the StarTeam interoperation with PVCS will work properly. The PVCS installation does not set the PATH environment variable, so this must be done manually. Be sure that the environment variable is either set for all users or set specifically for the user who starts the server.

  3. Verify that the PVCS command line is working.

  4. Place the PVCS archives to be wrapped on the same computer as the Server. Although this is not required, it reduces network traffic and, therefore, improves performance.

  5. Rename any files with problematic paths prior to wrapping.  StarTeam cannot process PVCS archives that contain parentheses in their file names or that have file paths with more than 128 characters. Some special characters, such as the backslash, are counted as two characters.

  6. Because StarTeam uses the PVCS configuration file (by default,vcs.cfg) to locate the PVCS files, verify that the path to this file and all the path names within it are recognized by the Server.

  7. Ensure that the directives listed in the configuration file are appropriate.

  8. Add the users in the PVCS archives to the server configuration that will manage the new project. The users’ logon IDs must be identical, except for case. For any revision author who is not listed as a user in the server configuration, StarTeam substitutes the name of the user creating the project. If an archive is locked by someone who is not found as a user in the server configuration and NOMULTILOCK is set, StarTeam shows the file as unlocked but does not allow a user to lock it.

    9. Tip: If PVCS and StarTeam Server run on NT systems and PVCS users use their NT logon names as PVCS logon names, you can import these user names into the Server to save time and prevent typographical errors.

  9. Check archives for labels. All labels must be unique. It is recommended that you use no more than one floating label per branch. All label names should be unique.

If your team decides to use StarTeam exclusively, you can convert the PVCS files to StarTeam files, stored in a StarTeam repository, after the wrapping process has taken place.

Note: Do not make any changes to the PVCS archives during the wrapping process.
